title: How to Freeze Garden Vegetables

steps.headline: Select young, freshly-picked vegetables.
steps.description: Garden vegetables that have already been sitting out for several days will lose some of their freshness, and freezing may cause them to lose additional flavor. To ensure that the vegetables stay fresh for as long as possible, choose vegetables that are just barely ripe or slightly unripe. Steer clear of overripe vegetables which may go bad even when frozen. Harvest your vegetables early in the morning and begin the freezing process immediately for best results.

steps.headline: Avoid vegetables with blemishes, bruises, and soft spots.
steps.description: If you do use damaged garden vegetables, remove these damaged spots before beginning the process. If the vegetable looks like it's close to rotting, avoid it.

steps.headline: Wash your vegetables.
steps.description: Even if the garden they came from is organic and free of potentially harmful pesticides, they will still be covered in dirt and bacteria. If necessary, use a potato brush to gently scrub away any stuck-on grime.

steps.headline: Cut up your vegetables.
steps.description: Remove any non-edible parts and chop the vegetables into your preferred size for eventual serving.

steps.headline: Fill a large pot with at least 1 or 2 gallons (4 to 8 liters) of water.
steps.description: A blancher pot, which holds 6 to 8 quarts (6 to 8 quarts) of water and contains a perforated basket for holding food, works best, but any large pot that comes with a lid will also work.

steps.headline: Boil the water over high heat.
steps.description: The water should reach a full rolling boil before you add the vegetables.

steps.headline: Place 1 pound (450 grams) of your prepared garden vegetables into a metal steaming basket.
steps.description: A wire-mesh strainer or cheesecloth bag may also work.

steps.headline: Lower the vegetables into the water.
steps.description: Make sure that they are completely immersed.

steps.headline: Cover the pot with a lid.
steps.description: Boil your vegetables for as long as necessary according to expert recommended boiling times. These times do vary. For instance, asparagus must boil for four minutes, while cut corn needs to water blanch for five minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the vegetables from the pot and immediately transfer them to a large container of ice water.
steps.description: By shocking the vegetables with ice water, you halt the cooking process and preserve the color of the vegetables. Keep the vegetables in the cold water for the same amount of time you kept them in boiling water. The water must be 60 degrees Fahrenheit (15.6 degrees Celsius) or lower. Use approximately 1 pint (500 milliliters) of water for each pound (450 grams) of vegetables.

steps.headline: Drain your vegetables completely.
Boil 1 to 2 inches (2 1/2 to 5 centimeters) of water in a large pot.
steps.description: You need a pot that has a lid and fits an interior rack. The rack must be positioned 3 inches (7.62) or more above the bottom of the pot.

steps.headline: Place a single layer of prepared garden vegetables in a steaming basket or cheesecloth bag.
steps.description: Do not pile the vegetables, since the steam needs to be evenly distributed. Select a garden vegetable that does well with the steam blanching method. Asparagus, broccoli, and chili peppers are among the best options. These vegetables benefit from slow steam blanching because this method allows them to retain more of their water-soluble vitamins, which might otherwise be lost by using standard water blanching.

steps.headline: Set the steaming basket on the rack inside the pot.
steps.description: Cover the pot and continue heating for as long as necessary according to expert recommendations for each vegetable.

steps.headline: Once the recommended blanching time has passed, remove the vegetables from the pot.
steps.description: Shock them by transferring the vegetables to a large bowl or pot of ice water. Allow the vegetables to sit in the icy water for the same amount of time they sat in the steam, using 1 pint (500 milliliters) water for every 1 pound (450 grams) of vegetables. Keep the water at a minimum of 60 degrees Fahrenheit (15.6 degrees Celsius), if not lower.

steps.headline: Drain your vegetables completely.
steps.description: Use a strainer or large pasta drainer to separate the vegetables from the ice water.

steps.headline: Lay blanched, drained vegetable pieces flat on a shallow tray.
steps.description: The vegetables should be arranged loosely in a single layer and should not overlap.

steps.headline: Place the tray in the freezer.
steps.description: Wait until the vegetables are firm before removing the tray.

steps.headline: Fill freezer bags or freezer containers with the frozen vegetables.
steps.description: You must leave an appropriate amount of empty space to allow the food a chance to expand as it freezes. Otherwise, you risk breaking the container. For container freezing, leave a 1/2-inch (1.27-centimeter) space between the top of the top of the vegetables and the rim of the container. When freezing in a plastic bag, leave a 3-inch (7.62-centimeter) space between the top of the vegetables and the top of the bag. Seal the bag and tie it shut with a rubber band placed 1/2-inch (1.27-centimeter) above the top of the food. Some garden vegetables, like green beans, beets, cabbage, carrots, onions, peas, peppers, and turnips, do not need to be tray frozen before being packed. For these vegetables, tightly pack the blanched, drained vegetables into containers and follow the same guidelines regarding empty space.

steps.headline: Label each bag or container with a felt tip marker.
steps.description: Write down the contents of the package and the date the food was first frozen.

steps.headline: Place the sealed, labeled packages into a freezer.
steps.description: For best results, only pack 2 to 3 pounds (900 to 1350 grams) of vegetables for each cubic foot. If the vegetables are packed any tighter than that, they may take too long to freeze.

steps.headline: Keep the temperature of your freezer set at 0 degrees Fahrenheit (-18 degrees Celsius).
steps.description: The majority of garden vegetables will retain their freshness, taste, and nutritional value for a year or longer if kept at this temperature.

text: Preparing the Vegetables Select young, freshly-picked vegetables. Garden vegetables that have already been sitting out for several days will lose some of their freshness, and freezing may cause them to lose additional flavor. To ensure that the vegetables stay fresh for as long as possible, choose vegetables that are just barely ripe or slightly unripe. Steer clear of overripe vegetables which may go bad even when frozen. Harvest your vegetables early in the morning and begin the freezing process immediately for best results. Avoid vegetables with blemishes, bruises, and soft spots. If you do use damaged garden vegetables, remove these damaged spots before beginning the process. If the vegetable looks like it's close to rotting, avoid it. Wash your vegetables. Even if the garden they came from is organic and free of potentially harmful pesticides, they will still be covered in dirt and bacteria. If necessary, use a potato brush to gently scrub away any stuck-on grime. Cut up your vegetables. Remove any non-edible parts and chop the vegetables into your preferred size for eventual serving. Water Blanching Fill a large pot with at least 1 or 2 gallons (4 to 8 liters) of water. A blancher pot, which holds 6 to 8 quarts (6 to 8 quarts) of water and contains a perforated basket for holding food, works best, but any large pot that comes with a lid will also work. Boil the water over high heat. The water should reach a full rolling boil before you add the vegetables. Place 1 pound (450 grams) of your prepared garden vegetables into a metal steaming basket. A wire-mesh strainer or cheesecloth bag may also work. Lower the vegetables into the water. Make sure that they are completely immersed. Cover the pot with a lid. Boil your vegetables for as long as necessary according to expert recommended boiling times. These times do vary. For instance, asparagus must boil for four minutes, while cut corn needs to water blanch for five minutes. Remove the vegetables from the pot and immediately transfer them to a large container of ice water. By shocking the vegetables with ice water, you halt the cooking process and preserve the color of the vegetables. Keep the vegetables in the cold water for the same amount of time you kept them in boiling water. The water must be 60 degrees Fahrenheit (15.6 degrees Celsius) or lower. Use approximately 1 pint (500 milliliters) of water for each pound (450 grams) of vegetables. Drain your vegetables completely.  Steam Blanching Boil 1 to 2 inches (2 1/2 to 5 centimeters) of water in a large pot. You need a pot that has a lid and fits an interior rack. The rack must be positioned 3 inches (7.62) or more above the bottom of the pot. Place a single layer of prepared garden vegetables in a steaming basket or cheesecloth bag. Do not pile the vegetables, since the steam needs to be evenly distributed. Select a garden vegetable that does well with the steam blanching method. Asparagus, broccoli, and chili peppers are among the best options. These vegetables benefit from slow steam blanching because this method allows them to retain more of their water-soluble vitamins, which might otherwise be lost by using standard water blanching. Set the steaming basket on the rack inside the pot. Cover the pot and continue heating for as long as necessary according to expert recommendations for each vegetable. Once the recommended blanching time has passed, remove the vegetables from the pot. Shock them by transferring the vegetables to a large bowl or pot of ice water. Allow the vegetables to sit in the icy water for the same amount of time they sat in the steam, using 1 pint (500 milliliters) water for every 1 pound (450 grams) of vegetables. Keep the water at a minimum of 60 degrees Fahrenheit (15.6 degrees Celsius), if not lower. Drain your vegetables completely. Use a strainer or large pasta drainer to separate the vegetables from the ice water. Packing and Storing Lay blanched, drained vegetable pieces flat on a shallow tray. The vegetables should be arranged loosely in a single layer and should not overlap. Place the tray in the freezer. Wait until the vegetables are firm before removing the tray. Fill freezer bags or freezer containers with the frozen vegetables. You must leave an appropriate amount of empty space to allow the food a chance to expand as it freezes. Otherwise, you risk breaking the container. For container freezing, leave a 1/2-inch (1.27-centimeter) space between the top of the top of the vegetables and the rim of the container. When freezing in a plastic bag, leave a 3-inch (7.62-centimeter) space between the top of the vegetables and the top of the bag. Seal the bag and tie it shut with a rubber band placed 1/2-inch (1.27-centimeter) above the top of the food. Some garden vegetables, like green beans, beets, cabbage, carrots, onions, peas, peppers, and turnips, do not need to be tray frozen before being packed. For these vegetables, tightly pack the blanched, drained vegetables into containers and follow the same guidelines regarding empty space. Label each bag or container with a felt tip marker. Write down the contents of the package and the date the food was first frozen. Place the sealed, labeled packages into a freezer. For best results, only pack 2 to 3 pounds (900 to 1350 grams) of vegetables for each cubic foot. If the vegetables are packed any tighter than that, they may take too long to freeze. Keep the temperature of your freezer set at 0 degrees Fahrenheit (-18 degrees Celsius). The majority of garden vegetables will retain their freshness, taste, and nutritional value for a year or longer if kept at this temperature.
